entry.title: Project Report
entry.summary:
In [4]: 
from IPython.display import Image

Flight Data: 1987-2008 Jonathan Chen, Connie Fee, Steven Hu, Bob Shao¶

Our Data

We pulled flight data from 1987 to 2008 from http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/the-data.html.

The files contain data on all domestic US commercial flights from 1987 to 2008. The data from all years combined consist of over 120 million rows and 29 columns. Each row represents a flight. The columns include (but are not limited to) the following information:

  • Year
  • Month
  • Day of Month
  • Day of Week
  • Scheduled Departure Time
  • Actual Departure Time
  • Scheduled Arrival Time
  • Actual Arrival Time
  • Scheduled Flight Time
  • Actual Flight Time
  • Departure Delay
  • Arrival Delay
  • Airport of Origin
  • Destination Airport
  • Flight Distance
  • Flight Number

Gathering the Data

Due to the large size of the raw data, we could not work with it directly in iPython Notebook. Instead, we turned to SQLite to construct an SQL database.

Using the database, we were able to look up and pull the data we wanted as we needed it, instead of attempting to load the data into RAM (which would not have worked due to the sheer size).

Goals

Our primary goal was to investigate delays, both by airport and over time. Some questions we try to address:

  • Are there substantial differences in delays between major airports?
  • Which major airports are the best/worst in terms of average delay?
  • What is the proportion of delayed flights, at each airport and overall?
  • What are trends in delays over the 22-year timespan of the data, both by airport and overall?
  • What factors may influence flight delays? (E.g. time of year, time of day, origin airport, destination airport, airline)

Basic Methodology

We first filtered the data and found the top 20 airports by number of originating flights. For our purposes, these would serve as the major airports we would investigate. The top 20 airports accounted for just over half of all flights between them.

The List:

  • ORD - Chicago O'Hare International Airport
  • ATL - Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport
  • DFW - Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport
  • LAX - Los Angeles International Airport
  • PHX - Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport
  • DEN - Denver International Airport
  • DTW - Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport
  • IAH - George Bush Intercontinental Airport
  • MSP - Minneapolis-SaintPaul International Airport Code
  • SFO - San Francisco International Airport
  • STL - Lambert-St. Louis International Airport
  • EWR - Newark Liberty International Airport
  • LAS - McCarran International Airport
  • CLT - Charlotte Douglas International Airport
  • LGA - LaGuardia Airport
  • BOS - Logan International Airport
  • PHL - Philadelphia International Airport
  • PIT - Pittsburgh International Airport
  • SLC - Salt Lake City International Airport
  • SEA - Seattle Tacoma International Airport

These airports became the focus of our analysis.

Data Cleaning

We pulled the relevant flights for each airport out of the database and saved them as CSV (with python scripts). However, despite filtering out unnecessary columns, we still needed to make some changes based on the delays.

Cancelled flights are removed, flights outside (-60, 500) for delay are removed (removing outliers, in-depth discussion in NB2), and all negative delays (early flights) are set to 0. This is because in evaluating delayed flights, an early flight is essentially the same as an on-time flight. It doesn't make sense to say that an airport that has 3 flights, with delays -5, 0, and 5, has an average delay of 0 minutes.

Analysis

First the basic analysis of flight delay statistics:

This first chart represents average delay times (airports on x-axis in alphabetical order), with non-delayed flights (0 delay) factored in. We see a clustering of average delays around 9-11 minutes, with a few unusually high airports, and unusually low airport.

In [11]: 
Image("../visualizations/index.png")
Out[11]:

This chart is the same, but with non-delayed flights removed from the averages.

In [9]: 
Image("../visualizations/plot-avg-delay-times.png")
Out[9]:

This chart displays the proportion of flights delayed, by airport:

In [10]: 
Image("../visualizations/proportion-flights-delayed.png")
Out[10]:

A histogram of average delay times in the top 20 airports:

In [13]: 
Image("../visualizations/histogram-avg-delay-times.png")
Out[13]:

And two time-series related graphs:

In [15]: 
Image("../visualizations/time-series-1.png")
Out[15]:
In [16]: 
Image("../visualizations/time-series-2.png")
Out[16]:
Call: glm(formula = logger ~ years) Deviance Residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -0.48230 -0.07539 0.03122 0.10615 0.33392 Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) 41.620425 13.509279 3.081 0.00589 ** years -0.020912 0.006763 -3.092 0.00575 ** --- Signif. codes: 0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 (Dispersion parameter for gaussian family taken to be 0.04050186) Null deviance: 1.19728 on 21 degrees of freedom Residual deviance: 0.81004 on 20 degrees of freedom AIC: -4.2045 Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 2

Thus, we can see time is a significant factor on effect of log-odds success on proportions of flights delayed. It appears that the average delay time has been increasing with time, while the proportion of delayed flights has been decreasing.

In []:

entry.title: Data Analysis
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll perform the actual analysis of the data stored in the directory

./data/cleaned

If the data is not ready yet (e.g. the other members of the team in charge of cleaning the data are not done yet), you may want to simulate cleaned data in the form you want them to be in order to perform the analysis. This may also help you data cleaning team to come up with the rigth data frame. If you choose to do so, store your simulated data into the directory

./data/simulated

Having performed analysis of simulated data may help you with the analysis of the actual data, since you will be able to notice deviations between the real and simulated data, which may be worth explaining and investigating further.

The graphics your going to produce as a result of your analysis should be store in the directory:

./visualization

Team members responsible for this notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • team member 1 name: team member 1 responsabilities
  • team member 2 name: team member 2 responsabilities
  • etc.

I advise you to work at least in pairs for each project notebook, as you did for the homework assignments. Of course, all team members may participate to each notebook.

In [1]: 
%load_ext rmagic
In [2]: 
%%R
ATL=read.csv("../data/cleaned/ATL.csv",header=FALSE)
BOS=read.csv("../data/cleaned/BOS.csv",header=FALSE)
CLT=read.csv("../data/cleaned/CLT.csv",header=FALSE)
DEN=read.csv("../data/cleaned/DEN.csv",header=FALSE)
DFW=read.csv("../data/cleaned/DFW.csv",header=FALSE)
DTW=read.csv("../data/cleaned/DTW.csv",header=FALSE)
EWR=read.csv("../data/cleaned/EWR.csv",header=FALSE)
IAH=read.csv("../data/cleaned/IAH.csv",header=FALSE)
LAS=read.csv("../data/cleaned/LAS.csv",header=FALSE)
LAX=read.csv("../data/cleaned/LAX.csv",header=FALSE)
LGA=read.csv("../data/cleaned/LGA.csv",header=FALSE)
MSP=read.csv("../data/cleaned/MSP.csv",header=FALSE)
ORD=read.csv("../data/cleaned/ORD.csv",header=FALSE)
PHL=read.csv("../data/cleaned/PHL.csv",header=FALSE)
PHX=read.csv("../data/cleaned/PHX.csv",header=FALSE)
PIT=read.csv("../data/cleaned/PIT.csv",header=FALSE)
SEA=read.csv("../data/cleaned/SEA.csv",header=FALSE)
SFO=read.csv("../data/cleaned/SFO.csv",header=FALSE)
SLC=read.csv("../data/cleaned/SLC.csv",header=FALSE)
STL=read.csv("../data/cleaned/STL.csv",header=FALSE)
In [3]: 
%%R
airports=rbind(ATL,BOS,CLT,DEN,DFW,DTW,EWR,IAH,LAS,LAX,LGA,MSP,ORD,PHL,PHX,PIT,SEA,SFO,SLC,STL)
delay=c(airports$V4)
origin=c(as.character(airports$V1))
data=data.frame(delay=delay,origin=origin)

Airline Comparisons¶

First, we compared each airport's average delay time.

In [4]: 
%%R
avgs=tapply(data$delay,data$origin,mean)
print(avgs)

      ATL       BOS       CLT       DEN       DFW       DTW       EWR       IAH 
11.270744 10.601876  9.752695 10.276824 10.202021 10.112165 12.504361  8.639502 
      LAS       LAX       LGA       MSP       ORD       PHL       PHX       PIT 
10.016496  9.064853  9.916390  8.880639 12.919656 11.849546  9.702281  9.381067 
      SEA       SFO       SLC       STL 
 9.485587 10.903367  7.865211  9.216288
In [5]: 
%%R
plot(unique(data$origin),avgs,main="Average Delay Times by Airport",xlab="Airport",ylab="Average delay times (min)")
abline(h=mean(avgs),lty=2)
In [34]: 
%%R
hist(avgs,xlab="Average delay times (min)",main="Histogram of Average Delay Times")

Next, we wanted to verify if this matches

In [7]: 
%%R
carriers=unique(data$origin)
prop={}
for(i in 1:20){
    airport=data$delay[data$origin == carriers[i]]
    total=length(airport)
    del=length(airport[airport != 0])
    prop=c(prop,del/total)
    }
table=data.frame(carriers=carriers, prop=prop)
print(table)

   carriers      prop
1       ATL 0.5295946
2       BOS 0.4195840
3       CLT 0.5165910
4       DEN 0.4626000
5       DFW 0.4965155
6       DTW 0.4151824
7       EWR 0.4359185
8       IAH 0.4093387
9       LAS 0.4269760
10      LAX 0.4418887
11      LGA 0.4081828
12      MSP 0.3720727
13      ORD 0.5053018
14      PHL 0.4994521
15      PHX 0.4338250
16      PIT 0.5197303
17      SEA 0.4156508
18      SFO 0.4516042
19      SLC 0.4249509
20      STL 0.3957319
In [9]: 
%%R
plot(table$carriers,table$prop,main="Proportion of Flights Delayed by Airport",xlab="Airport",ylab="Proportion delayed")
abline(h=mean(table$prop),lty=2)
In [25]: 
%%R
d=data
d[d==0]=NA
avgs2=tapply(d$delay,d$origin,mean,na.rm=TRUE)
print(avgs2)

     ATL      BOS      CLT      DEN      DFW      DTW      EWR      IAH 
21.28183 25.26759 18.87895 22.21536 20.54723 24.35596 28.68509 21.10600 
     LAS      LAX      LGA      MSP      ORD      PHL      PHX      PIT 
23.45915 20.51388 24.29399 23.86802 25.56819 23.72509 22.36450 18.04987 
     SEA      SFO      SLC      STL 
22.82105 24.14363 18.50852 23.28922
In [27]: 
%%R
plot(unique(data$origin),avgs2,main="Average Delay Times by Airport",xlab="Airport",ylab="Average delay times (min)")
In [26]: 
%%R
par(mfrow=c(1,3))
plot(unique(data$origin),avgs,main="Average Delay Times by Airport",xlab="Airport",ylab="Average delay times (min)")
plot(unique(data$origin),avgs2,main="Average Delay Times by Airport",xlab="Airport",ylab="Average delay times (min)")
plot(table$carriers,table$prop,main="Proportion of Flights Delayed by Airport",xlab="Airport",ylab="Proportion delayed")

Time Series Analysis

In [4]: 
%%R
t1987=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1987]
t1988=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1988]
t1989=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1989]
t1990=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1990]
t1991=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1991]
t1992=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1992]
t1993=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1993]
t1994=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1994]
t1995=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1995]
t1996=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1996]
t1997=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1997]
t1998=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1998]
t1999=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1999]
t2000=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2000]
t2001=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2001]
t2002=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2002]
t2003=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2003]
t2004=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2004]
t2005=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2005]
t2006=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2006]
t2007=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2007]
t2008=airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2008]
combined=c(t1987,t1988,t1989,t1990,t1991,t1992,t1993,t1994,t1995,t1996,t1997,t1998,t1999,t2000,t2001,t2002,t2003,t2004,t2005,t2006,t2007,t2008)
timeseries <- ts(combined)
plot.ts(timeseries)
library("TTR")
timeseriesSMA3 <- SMA(timeseries,n=10)
plot.ts(timeseriesSMA3)

Loading required package: xts
Loading required package: zoo

Attaching package: ‘zoo’

The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’:

    as.Date, as.Date.numeric
In [5]: 
%%R
expsmooth <- HoltWinters(timeseries, beta=FALSE, gamma=FALSE)
expsmooth

Holt-Winters exponential smoothing without trend and without seasonal component.

Call:
HoltWinters(x = timeseries, beta = FALSE, gamma = FALSE)

Smoothing parameters:
 alpha: 0.03294331
 beta : FALSE
 gamma: FALSE

Coefficients:
      [,1]
a 6.808911
In [1]: 
%%R
a = expsmooth$fitted

ERROR: Cell magic `%%R` not found.

** Log-odds success of proportions flights delayed as function over time **

In [8]: 
%%R
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1987 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1987]
odds1987 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1988 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1988]
odds1988 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1989 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1989]
odds1989 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1990 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1990]
odds1990 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1991 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1991]
odds1991 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1992 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1992]
odds1992 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1993 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1993]
odds1993 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1994 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1994]
odds1994 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1995 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1995]
odds1995 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1996 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1996]
odds1996 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1997 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1997]
odds1997 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1998 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1998]
odds1998 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1999 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 1999]
odds1999 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2000 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2000]
odds2000 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2001 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2001]
odds2001 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2002 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2002]
odds2002 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2003 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2003]
odds2003 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2004 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2004]
odds2004 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2005 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2005]
odds2005 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2006 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2006]
odds2006 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2007 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2007]
odds2007 = length(log)/length(num)
log = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2008 & airports$V4>0]
num = airports$V4[airports$V2 == 2008]
odds2008 = length(log)/length(num)
years=c(1987,1988,1989,1990,1991,1992,1993,1994,1995,1996,1997,1998,1999,2000,2001,2002,2003,2004,2005,2006,2007,2008)
logger2 = c(odds1987/(1-odds1987),odds1988/(1-odds1988),odds1989/(1-odds1989),odds1990/(1-odds1990),odds1991/(1-odds1991),odds1992/(1-odds1992),odds1993/(1-odds1993),odds1994/(1-odds1994),odds1995/(1-odds1995),odds1996/(1-odds1996),odds1997/(1-odds1997),odds1998/(1-odds1998),odds1999/(1-odds1999),odds2000/(1-odds2000),odds2001/(1-odds2001),odds2002/(1-odds2002),odds2003/(1-odds2003),odds2004/(1-odds2004),odds2005/(1-odds2005),odds2006/(1-odds2006),odds2007/(1-odds2007),odds2008/(1-odds2008))
logger=log(logger2)
trend=glm(logger~years)
trend
summary(trend)


Call:
glm(formula = logger ~ years)

Deviance Residuals: 
     Min        1Q    Median        3Q       Max  
-0.48230  -0.07539   0.03122   0.10615   0.33392  

Coefficients:
             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)   
(Intercept) 41.620425  13.509279   3.081  0.00589 **
years       -0.020912   0.006763  -3.092  0.00575 **
---
Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1

(Dispersion parameter for gaussian family taken to be 0.04050186)

    Null deviance: 1.19728  on 21  degrees of freedom
Residual deviance: 0.81004  on 20  degrees of freedom
AIC: -4.2045

Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 2

Thus, we can see time is a significant factor on effect of log-odds success on proportions of flights delayed.

entry.title: Data Cleaning
entry.summary:
Team members responsible for this notebook:

  • Steven Hu: Writeup, code for cleaning
  • Bob Shao: Deciding what/how to clean
  • Connie Fee: Deciding what/how to clean

Data Cleaning¶

In [2]: 
%load_ext rmagic

We've already done a lot of the organizing of the data we want when we pulled the csv files from the database in the previous notebook. But we still need to do a little more cleaning/filtering of the data.

First, let's just get an idea of what our data really looks like, in terms of flight departure delays. For now, we'll just look at the flights originating from ATL

In [27]: 
%%R
data = read.csv('../data/raw/ATL.csv', header=F)
plot(data$V4)

We'll assume ATL is somewhat representative of other airports. The graph shows that there are clear outliers, particularly on the low end. Graphically, we can see that almost all of the data (there are over 6 million points here) are between -60 and 500. So we will set those arbitrary cutoffs for deleting outliers. The following plot for another airport shows something similar.

In [28]: 
%%R
data = read.csv('../data/raw/SLC.csv', header=F)
plot(data$V4)
In [7]: 
import sqlite3
database = sqlite3.connect('../data/raw/ontime.sqlite3')
cur = database.cursor()
cur.execute('SELECT Count(*) FROM ontime WHERE (DepDelay < -60) AND (Cancelled = 0)')
print cur.fetchone()

(889,)
In [6]: 
cur.execute('SELECT Count(*) FROM ontime WHERE (DepDelay > 500) AND (Cancelled = 0)')
print cur.fetchone()

(17099,)

As you can see, in the entire database there are 889 non-cancelled flights with departure delays of less than -60 minutes, and 17099 flights with non-cancelled departure delays of over 500 minutes. Therefore, based on the graphical representation and these figures, it seems reasonable to use these cutoffs to remove extreme outliers.

In [25]: 
import csv

airports = [u'ORD', u'ATL', u'DFW', u'LAX', u'PHX', u'DEN', u'DTW', u'IAH', u'MSP', u'SFO', u'STL', u'EWR', u'LAS', u'CLT', u'LGA', u'BOS', u'PHL', u'PIT', u'SLC', u'SEA']
for i in airports:
    read = open('../data/raw/%s.csv' % i,'r')
    write = open('../data/cleaned/%s.csv' % i, 'w')
    reader = csv.reader(read)
    writer = csv.writer(write)
    for j in reader:
        if j[3] == 'NA':
            continue
        elif int(j[3]) < 0:
            if int(j[3]) < -60:
                continue
            else:
                j[3] = 0
                writer.writerow(j[:4])
        elif int(j[3]) > 500:
            continue
        else:
            writer.writerow(j[:4])
    read.close()
    write.close()

This writes new, cleaned csv files. Cancelled flights are removed, flights outside (-60, 500) for delay are removed, and all negative delays (early flights) are set to 0. This is because in evaluating delayed flights, an early flight is essentially the same as an on-time flight. It doesn't make sense to say that an airport that has 3 flights, with delays -5, 0, and 5, has an average delay of 0 minutes.

Other than this stuff, the data we need is all in good shape. No issues like missing fields.

In [10]: 
%%R
airports = c('ORD', 'ATL', 'DFW', 'LAX', 'PHX', 'DEN', 'DTW', 'IAH', 'MSP', 'SFO', 'STL', 'EWR', 'LAS', 'CLT', 'LGA', 'BOS', 'PHL', 'PIT', 'SLC', 'SEA')
ATL = read.csv('../data/cleaned/ATL.csv', header=F)
print(head(ATL))

   V1   V2 V3 V4
1 ATL 2008  1  0
2 ATL 2008  1  0
3 ATL 2008  1 33
4 ATL 2008  1  0
5 ATL 2008  1  0
6 ATL 2008  1  0
In []:

entry.title: Data Gathering
entry.summary:
Team members responsible for this notebook:

  • Steven Hu: Writing up, creating database, bash script, code to interface with database
  • Bob Shao: Assisting with creating database

Data Gathering¶

Creating Directory Structure¶

In [6]: 
%%bash
mkdir ../script ../data ../data/raw ../data/cleaned ../data/simulated ../visualizations
ls -r

README.md
NB4_project_report.ipynb
NB3_data_analysis.ipynb
NB2_data_cleaning.ipynb
NB1_data_gathering.ipynb

Description of the Data¶

We pulled flight data from 1987 to 2008 from http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/the-data.html, downloading all 20 years. The data came in archived/compressed .csv files (comma-separated variables).

The files contain data on domestic US flights from 1987 to 2008. The data from all years combined consist of over 100 million rows and 29 columns. Each row represents a flight. The columns include (but are not limited to) the following information:

  • Year
  • Month
  • Day of Month
  • Day of Week
  • Scheduled Departure Time
  • Actual Departure Time
  • Scheduled Arrival Time
  • Actual Arrival Time
  • Scheduled Flight Time
  • Actual Flight Time
  • Departure Delay
  • Arrival Delay
  • Airport of Origin
  • Destination Airport
  • Flight Distance
  • Flight Number

Downloading the Data¶

In [69]: 
%%bash
#note: don't run this stuff unless you're really sure, the files are large

#cd ../data/raw
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1987.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1988.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1989.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1990.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1991.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1992.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1993.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1994.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1995.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1996.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1997.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1998.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/1999.csv.bz2
#wget http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/2000.csv.bz2

Creating the Database¶

Due to the large size of the raw data, we could not work with it directly in iPython Notebook. Instead, we turned to SQLite to construct an SQL database.

Start sqlite3, create database
$ sqlite3 ontime.sqlite3


Create table
sqlite> create table ontime (
...> Year int,
...> Month int,
...> DayofMonth int,
...> DayOfWeek int,
...> DepTime int,
...> CRSDepTime int,
...> ArrTime int,
...> CRSArrTime int,
...> UniqueCarrier varchar(5),
...> FlightNum int,
...> TailNum varchar(8),
...> ActualElapsedTime int,
...> CRSElapsedTime int,
...> AirTime int,
...> ArrDelay int,
...> DepDelay int,
...> Origin varchar(3),
...> Dest varchar(3),
...> Distance int,
...> TaxiIn int,
...> TaxiOut int,
...> Cancelled int,
...> CancellationCode varchar(1),
...> Diverted varchar(1),
...> CarrierDelay int,
...> WeatherDelay int,
...> NASDelay int,
...> SecurityDelay int,
...> LateAircraftDelay int
...> );


Import the data from .csv
sqlite> .separator ,
sqlite> .import 2008.csv ontime
sqlite> .import 2007.csv ontime
sqlite> .import 2006.csv ontime
sqlite> .import 2005.csv ontime
etc...


Remove imported header rows
sqlite> delete from ontime where typeof(year) == "text";


Add some indices for convenience later
sqlite> create index year on ontime(year);
sqlite> create index origin on ontime(origin);
sqlite> create index uniquecarrier on ontime(uniquecarrier);
sqlite> create index month on ontime(month);

Now we have a database with the relevant raw flight data we downloaded. We can now access the data in iPython Notebook via Python commands, using the sqlite3 package.

Narrowing it Down¶

We don't want to look at all of the data, since it's not all relevant to our interests. We will narrow it down to fit the scope of our investigation. First of all, we are interested in classifying flights by their airport of origin. And we will look at the 20 airports with the most originating flights. So we produce a list of those airports as follows:

In [43]: 
import sqlite3, csv
database = sqlite3.connect('../data/raw/ontime.sqlite3')
In [48]: 
cur = database.cursor()
cur.execute('SELECT DISTINCT Origin FROM ontime')
airports = cur.fetchall()
flights = []
for i in airports:
    cur.execute('SELECT Count(*) FROM ontime WHERE (Origin = ?)', i)
    flights.append((i[0], cur.fetchone()[0]))
airport_flights = sorted(flights, key=lambda flight: flight[1], reverse=True)
In [49]: 
top_airports = []
flight_total = 0
for i in range (0, 20):
    top_airports.append(airport_flights[i][0])
    flight_total += airport_flights[i][1]
print top_airports
print flight_total

print airport_flights[0][1]
print airport_flights[19][1]

[u'ORD', u'ATL', u'DFW', u'LAX', u'PHX', u'DEN', u'DTW', u'IAH', u'MSP', u'SFO', u'STL', u'EWR', u'LAS', u'CLT', u'LGA', u'BOS', u'PHL', u'PIT', u'SLC', u'SEA']
64067176
6597442
1984077

Above, you see a list of the top 20 airports, and the total number of flights that originate from those airports. These represent just over half of the total flights from 1987-2008.

We'll also look at the top 5 airlines:

In [46]: 
cur = database.cursor()
cur.execute('SELECT DISTINCT UniqueCarrier FROM ontime')
airlines = cur.fetchall()
flights = []
for i in airlines:
    cur.execute('SELECT Count(*) FROM ontime WHERE (UniqueCarrier = ?)', i)
    flights.append((i[0], cur.fetchone()[0]))
airline_flights = sorted(flights, key=lambda flight: flight[1], reverse=True)
In [53]: 
top_airlines = []
flight_total = 0
for i in range (0, 5):
    top_airlines.append(airline_flights[i][0])
    flight_total += airline_flights[i][1]
print top_airlines
print flight_total

[u'DL', u'WN', u'AA', u'US', u'UA']
74883886

Now we gather the relevant data into .csv files. For each airport we care about, we will find all flights originating there, and get the year, month, departure delay, cancellation status, and cancellation code for each flight.

In [70]: 
#writes the necessary csvs for airports

for i in range (0, 20):
    cur.execute('SELECT Origin, Year, Month, DepDelay, Cancelled, CancellationCode FROM ontime WHERE (Origin = ?)', (airport_flights[i][0],))
    writer = csv.writer(open("../data/raw/%s.csv" % airport_flights[i][0], "w"))
    writer.writerows(cur)

Same as above, except for the airlines rather than airports.

In [71]: 
#writes the necessary csvs for airlines

for i in range (0, 5):
    cur.execute('SELECT UniqueCarrier, Year, Month, DepDelay, Cancelled, CancellationCode FROM ontime WHERE (UniqueCarrier = ?)', (airline_flights[i][0],))
    writer = csv.writer(open("../data/raw/%s.csv" % airline_flights[i][0], "w"))
    writer.writerows(cur)

Note that while we have saved these files into the cleaned folder, they aren't completely cleaned yet. See next notebook.
